Hi Wesley, congrats on the GECCO paper and also thanks for sharing the so=
ftware.  I do have a couple questions/comments:  

The subculture idea is i=
nteresting but did you consider aligning the subcultures with the NEAT-dete=
rmined species divisions?  It seems strange that a "subculture" could cut a=
cross species, though I suppose the existence of dogs and cats in human hou=
seholds is sort of analogous.  On the other hand when you can actually "lea=
rn" to be almost identical to another species (as you can when you are just=
 a neural network) maybe it doesn't really matter that much what species yo=
u started from.

On a more philosophical level, it's interesting that teach=
ing in general is a kind of convergent force towards conformity.  Obviously=
 some of that is necessary in society, but it raises the question of whethe=
r societies transmit creativity through teaching (or at least can avoid dam=
aging creativity when teaching).  This question is a bit abstract, but it d=
oes relate to novelty search - the kind of divergent proliferation of stepp=
ing stones seen in non-objective search is potentially inhibited in a socia=
l learning society.  So it raises the question of whether you can actually =
have both social transmission and non-objective divergence together.  Inter=
estingly, human society seems to have both ingredients working very effecti=
vely together.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@...=
> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> I'm proud to announce my first GECCO paper!
> 
> =
Title: Accelerating Evolution via Egalitarian Social Learning
> Authors: We=
sley Tansey, Eliana Feasley, and Risto Miikkulainen
> 
> Abstract:
> Social=
 learning is an extension to evolutionary algorithms that enables
> agents =
to learn from observations of others in the population.
> Historically, soc=
ial learning algorithms have employed a student-teacher
> model where the b=
ehavior of one or more high-fitness agents is used to
> train a subset of t=
he remaining agents in the population. This paper
> presents ESL, an egalit=
arian model of social learning in which agents are
> not labeled as teacher=
s or students, instead allowing any individual
> receiving a sufficiently h=
igh reward to teach other agents to mimic its
> recent behavior. We validat=
e our approach through a series of experiments
> in a robot foraging domain=
, including comparisons of egalitarian social
> learning with baseline neur=
oevolution and a variant of student-teacher
> social learning. In a complex=
 foraging task, ESL converges to near-optimal
> strategies faster than eith=
er benchmark approach, outperforming both by
> more than an order of magnit=
ude. The results indicate that egalitarian
> social learning is a promising=
 new paradigm for social learning in
> intelligent agents.
> 
> Paper page:=
 http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=3D127157
> 
> Github repository=
 for all source code:
> https://github.com/tansey/social-learning
> 
> A co=
uple of things to note here that I believe will be very helpful to
> anyone=
 using SharpNEAT in general:
> 
> - If you're looking to do Lamarckian evol=
ution, it turns out to be very
> easy: https://gist.github.com/2410490
> 
>=
 - We implemented backpropagation through time for the FastCyclicNetwork.
>=
 Using the SharpNeatV2 that is in the github repo, you can perform
> superv=
ised learning on a NEAT network very easily, enabling online learning
> alg=
orithms to be incorporated into SharpNEAT experiments:
> https://gist.githu=
b.com/2410545
> 
> Colin, I'd love if you could take a look at the backprop=
 implementation and
> potentially integrate it into a future release of Sha=
rpNEAT. Outside of our
> hacking of the FastCyclicNetwork class, it only re=
quired changing
> permissions on a few properties here and there.
> 
> The =
caveats here are that the backprop implementation requires you reset
> the =
network state at every activation to be correct. If you're doing
> somethin=
g where recurrent networks that maintain state between calls are
> required=
, then the performance of this method is not guaranteed to work.
> 
> If an=
yone has any comments or questions on the paper, I'm happy to discuss
> it!=

> 
> Sincerely,
> Wesley
>
